Jimmer provides out-of-the-box cache data consistency guarantees. All developers have to do is simply enable Jimmer's trigger feature to make it perceive and response database changes. The cache consistency is fully automated for applications with only object cache and associative cache, no extra works need to do. Very simple manual assistance is required for applications with computed cache or multi-view cache Example The corresponding associative cache and computed cache would be cleared automatically when a foreign key modified. View gif animation In this animation, the white area above is the SQL tool, and the black area below is the Intellij log. The associative attribute BookStore.books is affected, which further affects the computed attribute BookStore.avgPrice. The corresponding associative cache would be cleared automatically when intermediate tables modified. View gif animation In this animation, the white area above is the SQL tool, and the black area below is the Intellij log. The corresponding computed cache would be cleared automatically when the dependent fields modified. View gif animation In this animation, the white area above is the SQL tool, and the black area below is the Intellij log. The corresponding associative and computed cache would be cleared automatically when the fields that the filter depends on modified. View gif animation In this animation, the white area above is the SQL tool, and the black area below is the Intellij log. In this example, the global filter operates on the Book object, all associative attributes BookStore.books and Author.books pointing to it are affected. The computed attribute BookStore.avgPrice is further affected since the associative attribute BookStore.books changes.
Errors are found at compile-time as much as possible; strongly typed DSL can be also mixed with Native SQL.

Jimmer strongly typed DSL provides more useful features than native SQL for multi-table JOIN. Building paths of any length with chained expressions by the help of intellisence based on object properties is multi-level JOIN. Conflicting table JOINs in the different paths could be merged automatically, and redundant JOINs would be optimized out automatically. This is probably the first ORM without the "JOIN" operator In fact, its the original motivation for Jimmer. Link: Table Joins
Query for row counting required by paging would be generated and optimized automatically based on data object query. Link: Pagination query

Jimmer provides two kinds of triggers to notify data changes before and after a transaction commit respectively. Each could perceive the data changes, including object changes and association changes. Link: Trigger
Link: Benchmark.

Do not restrict the microservice governance framework, allow entity objects to support remote associations across microservice boundaries. While SQL grouping and aggregation can be used to implement computed attributes, these sorts of statistical operations are not the area the relational OLTP databases are best at, we may support mapping computed attributes to column-based OLAP databases like Clickhouse in future. The available features are slightly beyond the scope of ORM, but we still interpret Jimmer as ORM currently. We will interpret Jimmer in a new way when it goes far beyond ORM after these features implemented, and the future is coming now.

Use intellij to open <jimmer-home>/example/java/java-sql or <jimmer-home>/example/kotlin/java-sql-kt, After opening it for the first time, compilation errors will appear in the IDE, please refer to Open Demo with IDE Start it, Access http://localhost:8080/ui For more information, please view Demos

caution Like other strong type dsl frameworks, jimmer uses a code generator, which is AnnotationProcessor for Java and KSP for Kotlin. Therefore, when you open any project in the demo with the framework attached to the IDE for the first time, compilation errors will be reported because the code that should be automatically generated does not exist temporarily. Don't be afraid, click the "Run" button with confidence, and all problems will disappear automatically and immediately.

Spring Boot 2.7.0 brings Spring GraphQL, and jimmer-sql provides a specialized API to speed up the development of Spring GraphQL. note Notice: GraphQL and Object Fetcher are two ways to a similar end. Object Fetcher focuses on supporting this capability at the SQL level, and GraphQL focuses on exposing this capability. Once you decide to use Spring GraphQL, don't use Object Fetcher, each query method of the controller only needs to return a single object or its collection, GraphQL will shoulder similar responsibilities as Object Fetcher.

For fields of type Query, i.e. root queries, there is no difference between a GraphQL implementation and a REST implementation, and no special support is required. The key point is the query for associations between objects. It is a simple concept in itself, but for performance, DataLoader is usually used in actual projects, and DataLoader has caused great damage to the development experience. note Association queries and DataLoader increase the difficulty of developing GraphQL services, but because of this, GraphQL services are very powerful from the client's point of view. In order to alleviate the disruption of DataLoader to the development experience, Spring GraphQL introduces a new annotation @BatchMapping. jimmer-sql provides special support for this, providing dedicated API that allows developers to implement Spring GraphQL's @BatchMapping method in one sentence. API related to this Java Kotlin Computed property JSqlClient.getLoaders().value KSqlClient.loaders.value Reference association JSqlClient.getLoaders().reference KSqlClient.loaders.reference List association JSqlClient.getLoaders().list KSqlClient.loaders.list

ReferenceLoadder is used to quickly implement one-to-one or many-to-one associations Java Kotlin BookController.java @Controller public class BookController { private final JSqlClient sqlClient; public BookController(JSqlClient sqlClient) { this.sqlClient = sqlClient; } // Many-to-one associaton: Book.store @BatchMapping public Map<Book, BookStore> store( Collection<Book> books ) { return sqlClient .getLoaders() .reference(BookProps.STORE) .batchLoad(books); } } BookController.kt @Controller class BookController( private val sqlClient: KSqlClient ) { // Many-to-one associaton: Book.store @BatchMapping fun store( // Must use `java.util.List` because Spring-GraphQL has a bug: #454 books: java.util.List<Book> ): Map<Book, BookStore> = sqlClient .loaders .reference(Book::store) .batchLoad(books) } danger For kotlin, java.util.List must be used implicitly, kotlin list cannot work. This is a bug of spring-graphql, please view spring-graphql#454

ListLoader is used to quickly implement one-to-many or many-to-many associations Java Kotlin BookStoreController.java @Controller public class BookStoreController { private final JSqlClient sqlClient; public BookStoreController(JSqlClient sqlClient) { this.sqlClient = sqlClient; } // One-to-many associaton: BookStore.books @BatchMapping public Map<BookStore, List<Book>> books( List<BookStore> bookStores ) { return sqlClient .getLoaders() .list(BookStoreProps.BOOKS) .batchLoad(bookStores); } } BookStoreController.kt @Controller class BookController( private val sqlClient: KSqlClient ) { // One-to-many associaton: BookStore.books @BatchMapping fun books( // Must use `java.util.List` because Spring-GraphQL has a bug: #454 stores: java.util.List<BookStore> ): Map<BookStore, List<Book>> = sqlClient .loaders .list(BookStore::books) .batchLoad(stores) } Java Kotlin BookController.java @Controller public class BookController { private final JSqlClient sqlClient; public BookController(JSqlClient sqlClient) { this.sqlClient = sqlClient; } // Many-to-many associaton: Book.authors @BatchMapping public Map<Book, List<Author>> authors(List<Book> books) { return sqlClient .getLoaders() .list(BookProps.AUTHORS) .batchLoad(books); } } BookController.kt @Controller class BookController( private val sqlClient: KSqlClient ) { // Many-to-many associaton: Book.authors @BatchMapping fun authors( // Must use `java.util.List` because Spring-GraphQL has a bug: #454 books: java.util.List<Book> ): Map<Book, List<Author>> = sqlClient .loaders .list(Book::authors) .batchLoad(books) } Java Kotlin AuthorController.java @Controller public class AuthorController { private final JSqlClient sqlClient; public AuthorController(JSqlClient sqlClient) { this.sqlClient = sqlClient; } // Many-to-many associaton: Author.books @BatchMapping public Map<Author, List<Book>> books( List<Author> authors ) { return sqlClient .getLoaders() .list(AuthorProps.BOOKS) .batchLoad(authors); } } AuthorController.kt @Controller class AuthorController( private val sqlClient: KSqlClient ) { // Many-to-many associaton: Author.books @BatchMapping fun books( // Must use `java.util.List` because Spring-GraphQL has a bug: #454 authors: java.util.List<Author> ): Map<Author, List<Book>> = sqlClient .loaders .list(Author::books) .batchLoad(authors) } danger For kotlin, java.util.List must be used implicitly, kotlin list cannot work. This is a bug of spring-graphql, please view spring-graphql#454

ValueLoader is used to quickly implement calculated property. jimmer-sql supports calculated property, which means transient property with resolver. Java Kotlin BookStore.java @Entity public interface BookStore { @Transient(BookStoreAvgPriceResolver.class) BigDecimal avgPrice(); ... Omit other properties ... } BookStore.kt @Entity interface BookStore { @Transient(BookStoreAvgPriceResolver::class) val avgPrice: BigDecimal ... Omit other properties ... } ValueLoader should be used like this Java Kotlin BookStoreController.java @Controller public class BookStoreController { private static final ImmutableProp BOOK_STORE_DOT_AVG_PRICE = ImmutableType .get(BookStore.class) .getProp("avgPrice"); private final JSqlClient sqlClient; public BookController(JSqlClient sqlClient) { this.sqlClient = sqlClient; } // Calculated property: BookStore.avgPrice @BatchMapping public Map<BookStore, BigDecimal> avgPrice( List<BookStore> stores ) { return sqlClient .getLoaders() .<BookStore, BigDecimal>value( BOOK_STORE_DOT_AVG_PRICE ) .batchLoad(stores); } } BookStoreController.kt @Controller class BookStoreController( private val sqlClient: KSqlClient ) { // Calculated property: BookStore.avgPrice // hightlight-next-line @BatchMapping fun avgPrice( // Must use `java.util.List` because Spring-GraphQL has a bug: #454 stores: java.util.List<BookStore> ): Map<BookStore, BigDecimal> = sqlClient .loaders // hightlight-next-line .value(BookStore::avgPrice) .batchLoad(stores) } danger For kotlin, java.util.List must be used implicitly, kotlin list cannot work. This is a bug of spring-graphql, please view spring-graphql#454

Before introducing the mutation, we need to discuss why the GraphQL protocol introduced the Input type. From an output perspective, a GraphQL field returns an Object type. However, from an input perspective, the parameters of GraphQL fields do not accept Object types, only scalar types, Input types, and their collection types are acceptable. The different between Object and Input: The Object type is dynamic, and the client can freely define the shape of the object. The dynamic nature of the Object type realizes the core value of GraphQL, clients can specify which fields are required and which are not, giving them flexibility in controlling the format of the object tree to query. The Input type is static, and the client must provide parameters that strictly meet the server's requirements. Different from query, the mutation business often has strict restrictions on the input data format. If the client arbitrarily passes the data format that does not meet the expectations of the server, it may lead to abnormal business. Therefore, the GraphQL protocol introduces the Input type, which is static, and the client must pass a data format that strictly conforms to the Input type definition before calling the mutation business. This difference is the fundamental reason for the existence of the Input type.
documents.s: Existence value of GraphQL Input type

documents.t: First, we need to define the input type in the Spring GraphQL convention file src/main/resources/graphql/schema.graphqls input BookInput { id: Long name: String! edition: Int price: BigDecimal! storeId: Long authorIds: [Long!]! } Then, in the Java code, define the corresponding class BookInput Java Kotlin BookInput.java public class BookInput { @Nullable private final Long id; private final String name; private final int edition; private final BigDecimal price; @Nullable private final Long storeId; private final List<Long> authorIds; public BookInput( @Nullable Long id, String name, int edition, BigDecimal price, @Nullable Long storeId, List<Long> authorIds ) { this.id = id; this.name = name; this.edition = edition; this.price = price; this.storeId = storeId; this.authorIds = authorIds; } // Convert static input object to // dynamic entity object tree, // no matter how deep it is. public Book toBook() { return BookDraft.$.produce(book -> { if (id != null) { book.setId(id); } if (storeId != null) { book.setStore( store -> store.setId(storeId) ); } book .setName(name) .setEdition(edition) .setPrice(price); for (Long authorId : authorIds) { book.addIntoAuthors( author -> author.setId(authorId) ); } }); } } BookInput.kt data class BookInput( val id: Long?, // Optional id val name: String, val edition: Int, val price: BigDecimal, val storeId: Long?, val authorIds: List<Long> ) { // Convert static input(DTO) object to // dynamic entity object tree, // no matter how deep it is. fun toBook(): Book = new(Book::class).by { val that = this@BookInput that.id?.let { id = it } name = that.name edition = that.edition price = that.price that.storeId?.let { store().id = it } for (authorId in that.authorIds) { authors().addBy { id = authorId } } } } info The Save command of jimmer-sql provides the function of saving object tree with arbitrary complexity into database. Therefore, jimmer-sql focuses on the entity object tree, not the input object. So, we need to provide the method BookInput.toBook to convert the static BookInput object to a dynamic Book object. The Book object is a jimmer-core immutable object, which is dynamic, that is, the format of Book is ever-changing and all-encompassing. So, no matter how BookInput type is defined, and whether BookInput has deep data nesting, it can be converted to Book type. It can never happen that BookInput cannot be converted to Book. The core value of the BookInput is to conform to the GraphQL protocol and impose format constraints on the input data passed by the client. Howerver, for jimmer-sql, BookInput only has the responsibility of creating Book object. So, apart from the toBook method, the class BookInput in java code does not define any other methods, not even a getter methods, because this is unnessary (of course, if you want to cooperate with the debugger display function, you can define a toString for it).

Now, we know The Save command of jimmer-sql allows developers to use one sentence to save any complex entity object tree into the database. The BookInput defined above can be converted to an entity object tree of Book through its method toBook. Then, the realization of the data mutation business is very simple. Java Kotlin BookController.java @Controller public class BookController { private final JSqlClient sqlClient; public BookController(JSqlClient sqlClient) { this.sqlClient = sqlClient; } @MutationMapping @Transactional public Book saveBook(@Argument BookInput input) { return sqlClient .getEntities() .save( input.toBook() ) .getModifiedEntity(); } } BookController.kt @Controller class BookController( private val sqlClient: KSqlClient ) { @MutationMapping @Transactional fun saveBook(@Argument input: BookInput): Book = sqlClient .entities .save( input.toBook() ) .modifiedEntity }
